description: Sense of “factory hand” attested from 1946. Compare hunky, bohunk.

Term of racial abuse attested 1967, most likely from hunky (“Hungarian, Slav, eastern European; any white person”), an African-American vernacular shortening of Hungarian. Another possible etymon is Wolof xonq (“red, pink”), a term frequently used in African languages to describe white men.

entries.meaning: (Canada, US, derogatory, ethnic slur) A white (Caucasian) person.
(US, obsolete) A factory hand or general unskilled worker.
